Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Computer Science Research and Enrichment Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The Computer Science Research and Enrichment Program will provide an opportunity to translate the potential of a few promising students at Rutgers University-Camden and a few students from local high schools into measurable impact. As part of this project we will work very closely with these students over the next couple of years - teaching them advanced topics in discrete mathematics/algorithms, mentoring them, and working on research projects with them. Making a concerted effort to support and guide these students will enrich them individually, and also permit them to make a greater impact through their academic and professional endeavors. The research projects that we plan to work on are related to covering problems and scheduling problems. Like many other problems, the proposed problems are intractable and no efficient algorithms to solve these problems exactly are known. Our goal is to design efficient algorithms that produce near-optimal solutions for these problems.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University Camden
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main focus of this project was to work closely with students with various backgrounds on topics in Computer Science. We worked with high school students, undergraduate students, students with a different background wanting to change careers, and students who have finished their undergraduate degree but aren't sure of the next step.

The PI conducted summer programs in Computer Science - in 2010 at Rutgers University-Camden and in 2011 at Princeton University. These programs were about 8-week long and students (mostly high school students and a few undergraduates) spent 7-8 hours each weekday studying topics in Computer Science. Some students who had no intention of pursuing Computer Science degree in college are now majoring in Computer Science. A few high school students who attended both the summer programs are already studying advanced topics in Theoretical Computer Science, reading research articles, and attending conferences. At the end of the Princeton summer program the students presented the PI with a website that described the program. The website is at: http://rajivgandhics.wordpress.com . 

The PI also works with interested high school students on weekends during the school year.

The PI worked on research projects with students James Davis and Vijay Kothari. They worked on scheduling problems and have obtained results that have been submitted for review. James is currently a graduate student at Cornell and Vijay just started his graduate studies at Dartmouth.


Last Modified: 10/06/2011
Modified by: Rajiv C Gandhi
